S3.T1.caption: TABLE I: The Server and Users’ Knowledge in Different Stages
references: After federated learning, the server and users have more information in Stages III and IV compared with Stages I and II. For example, the users will know their training losses {ℓi}i∈ℐsubscriptsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑖ℐ\{\ell_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{I}}. The server can evaluate the users’ contribution to the global model (denoted by {vi}i∈ℐsubscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑖ℐ\{v_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{I}}), and it will know each user’s type by observing users’ contract item choices. We summarize their knowledge about some key information in the four stages in Table I and list the key notations in this paper in Table II.888As analyzing the four-stage game is complicated, this paper does not model the information update in a fully Bayesian framework but specifies plausible beliefs that the players hold in each stage.

S3.T2.caption: TABLE II: Key Notations
S3.T2.table:
θjsubscript𝜃𝑗\theta_{j} Marginal training cost of type-j𝑗j users
ξjsubscript𝜉𝑗\xi_{j} Marginal perceived privacy cost of type-j𝑗j users
Ijsubscript𝐼𝑗I_{j} Number of type-j𝑗j users
j/𝒥𝑗𝒥j/\mathcal{J} Index/Set of user types in the system
i/ℐ𝑖ℐi/\mathcal{I} Index/Set of users in the system
ℐusubscriptℐ𝑢\mathcal{I}_{u} Set of users who revoke their data in Stage III
ℐrsubscriptℐ𝑟\mathcal{I}_{r} Set of users who are retained by the server in Stage IV
ϕjsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑗\phi_{j} Contract item designed for type-j𝑗j users
djsubscript𝑑𝑗d_{j} Required data size for each type-j𝑗j user in the contract
rjLsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑗𝐿r_{j}^{L} Learning reward for each type-j𝑗j user in the contract
riUsuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑈r_{i}^{U} Unlearning reward (retention incentive) for user i𝑖i
xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} User i𝑖i’s data revocation decision
pjsubscript𝑝𝑗p_{j} Historical revocation rate of type-j𝑗j users
qjsubscript𝑞𝑗q_{j} Historical retention rate of type-j𝑗j users
T𝑇T Number of communication rounds of federated learning
λ𝜆\lambda Coefficient related to unlearning communication rounds
ϱitalic-ϱ\varrho Coefficient related to expected accuracy loss
γ𝛾\gamma Server’s weight on incentive rewards
visubscript𝑣𝑖v_{i} User i𝑖i’s contribution to global model accuracy
ℓisubscriptℓ𝑖\ell_{i} User i𝑖i’s training loss (representing ‖∇Fi​(x∗)‖norm∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝑥||\nabla F_{i}(x^{*})||)
references: After federated learning, the server and users have more information in Stages III and IV compared with Stages I and II. For example, the users will know their training losses {ℓi}i∈ℐsubscriptsubscriptℓ𝑖𝑖ℐ\{\ell_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{I}}. The server can evaluate the users’ contribution to the global model (denoted by {vi}i∈ℐsubscriptsubscript𝑣𝑖𝑖ℐ\{v_{i}\}_{i\in\mathcal{I}}), and it will know each user’s type by observing users’ contract item choices. We summarize their knowledge about some key information in the four stages in Table I and list the key notations in this paper in Table II.888As analyzing the four-stage game is complicated, this paper does not model the information update in a fully Bayesian framework but specifies plausible beliefs that the players hold in each stage.
